    Was told to boost asset values 'arbitrarily': Trump's ex-fixer
    Michael Cohen, Donald Trump's former fixer, testified in court that he inflated the value of Trump's assets based on the number Trump told him to. Cohen, who had previously vowed to protect Trump, became a key witness against him in various legal proceedings. He is now involved in a lawsuit by the New York Attorney General, alleging that Trump and his company deceived banks and insurers by inflating his wealth. Trump denies the allegations and dismisses Cohen as a liar.  ( 41 min )
    Wary of Israel's action plan: US officials
    The Biden administration is expressing concern that Israel may lack achievable military objectives and a workable plan for a ground invasion in Gaza. While the US still supports the idea of a ground invasion, senior administration officials have stressed the need for careful consideration and adherence to the law of war. The Pentagon has deployed Lt. Gen. James Glynn and other officers to assist Israel with the challenges of urban warfare, but they will not be on the ground if an incursion into Gaza occurs.  ( 43 min )
    'Will not let world forget': Israel screens raw footage of Hamas brutal massacre
    The Israeli military has shown nearly 44 minutes of raw footage to foreign reporters, depicting the aftermath of the Oct. 7 attacks by Hamas assailants. The footage, collected from various sources including body cameras, dashcams, and social media accounts, shows bloodied corpses, charred bodies, and brutalized individuals. The military aims to create a collective memory and ensure that the world does not forget the atrocities committed, which they describe as both a war crime and a crime against humanity.  ( 43 min )
    'Went through hell': Freed hostage, 85, recalls being in 'spider web' of tunnels
    Yocheved Lifshitz, an 85-year-old woman who was held hostage by Palestinian militants in Gaza, has described being beaten and taken through underground tunnels during her captivity. She is the first hostage to provide a public account of the conditions faced by the estimated 200 hostages held by Hamas and other armed groups in Gaza. Lifshitz was freed along with another woman, but their husbands remain in captivity. She recalled the horrors suffered by her neighbors during the attack on her town and stated that her kidnappers took care of her and provided medical treatment.  ( 43 min )
    Back in Pakistan, Nawaz Sharif gets bail in corruption cases
    Pakistan's former prime minister, Nawaz Sharif, has been granted bail in corruption cases until October 26. Sharif, who was convicted on corruption charges in 2017, returned to Pakistan last week after four years in self-exile in London. The Islamabad High Court extended his protective bail after prosecutors from the anti-graft agency raised no objections. Sharif's convictions remain in force, but the court has barred authorities from arresting him until Tuesday, when he is due to appear in court. His legal team plans to pursue appeals against the convictions, with the aim of overturning them.  ( 42 min )
    IDF posts videos of Hamas terrorists detailing orders to kill, behead and rape
    Israeli security agencies have released video footage of the interrogations of seven Hamas terrorists who were captured after the attacks on October 7. In the videos, the terrorists confessed to receiving orders to commit acts of violence against Israeli civilians, including beheading and raping victims. The terrorists were apprehended during an assault on Kibbutz Alumim, where they killed 16 people from Thailand and Nepal and took eight others as hostages. The video aimed to counter doubts about the horrific acts committed by Hamas.  ( 50 min )
    Female teacher, 24, accused of sexual misconduct with three of her students in US, including minors
    Former school teacher Cassidy Kraus has been charged with engaging in sexual relations with three students between the ages of 13 and 14. She is facing charges of sharing explicit material with a minor, engaging in inappropriate conduct with a child, and third-degree sexual abuse. If found guilty, she could face a substantial prison sentence. Kraus is no longer employed at the school where the incidents allegedly took place and has already posted bail. Kraus posted a $10,000 bond the morning after her arrest and is scheduled to appear in court again on October 26.  ( 44 min )
    Montana man pleads not guilty to charges that he threatened to kill former House Speaker McCarthy
    A Montana man pleaded not guilty to federal charges of threatening to assault and murder former House Speaker Kevin McCarthy. Richard Lee Rogers of Yellowstone County entered the plea during his initial appearance in federal court. Rogers is charged with threats to injure and murder a member of Congress, as well as making harassing telephone calls. The threats allegedly occurred in February and were intended as retaliation for McCarthy's actions as House speaker.  ( 42 min )
    UN agency says to halt Gaza work unless fuel arrives
    The UN agency for Palestinian refugees, UNRWA, has warned that it may have to stop operations in the Gaza Strip unless urgent fuel deliveries are made. Aid agencies have expressed concern about the lack of fuel, which is necessary to power essential services such as hospitals. Six hospitals have already closed due to the fuel shortage, and the World Health Organization has stated that the limited supplies currently available will only last for a little over 24 hours.  ( 42 min )
    UN chief pleads for Gazans' safety, cites humanitarian law violations
    UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres called for the protection of civilians in the conflict between Israel and Hamas. He expressed concerns about violations of international humanitarian law. Guterres also emphasized the importance of respecting and protecting civilians, while also acknowledging the grievances of the Palestinian people. Israel's UN Ambassador criticized Guterres' remarks, accusing him of having a sympathetic view towards terrorism.  ( 47 min )
    Worrying news for Indians in line for green card
    The wait for permanent residency (green card) for Indians in the employment-based 2 and 3 categories in the US is getting longer. There are currently 1.1 million Indians in the queue for green cards, with most in the EB-2 and EB-3 categories. The US Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS) has announced that no more EB-2 or EB-3 I-485s from India will be accepted during fiscal year 2024 and beyond. This imbalance between supply and demand for green cards can only be addressed by Congress.  ( 59 min )
    Ukraine's Siberian Battalion recruits Russians to help fight Moscow
    A group of 20 Russian citizens, dressed in Ukrainian uniforms, are training at a shooting range outside Kyiv to join Ukraine's newly-formed Siberian Battalion. A Ukrainian military officer, who asked to remain anonymous, said most of the unit's 50 members came from Russia, travelling through third countries to reach Ukraine. The officer said most are from among the indigenous peoples of Siberia and recruits said they want to fight against what they said was Russian imperialism.  ( 48 min )
    Turkish parliament commission set to study Swedish Nato bid
    Turkey's parliament speaker will send a bill approving Sweden's Nato membership bid to the foreign affairs commission. President Tayyip Erdogan submitted the bill on Monday, which must now be approved by the commission before being ratified by the general assembly. The commission chair will decide when to discuss the bill. Hungary will also make a decision regarding the ratification of Sweden's Nato bid. Finland's membership was sealed in April 2023.  ( 42 min )
    More than 100 detained in Egypt after pro-Palestinian protests: Lawyers
    Around 100 people were arrested in Egypt for participating in pro-Palestinian demonstrations last week, although some have since been released. The protests, approved by the state, were held in various locations, but some protesters walked to Tahrir Square, which was not authorized for the demonstration. The unauthorized protesters were quickly dispersed by security personnel. Unapproved public protests are banned in Egypt, and Tahrir Square is heavily monitored due to its symbolic significance.  ( 44 min )
    House Republicans to pick third Speaker nominee in as many weeks
    House Republicans are holding a fresh round of voting through secret ballots to select a candidate for the position of House Speaker, following the removal of Kevin McCarthy. Majority Leader Steve Scalise and House Judiciary Chairman Jim Jordan initially withdrew their candidacies due to insufficient support. Seven candidates are now in contention, including Jack Bergman, Byron Donalds, Tom Emmer, Mike Johnson, Kevin Hern, Austin Scott, and Pete Sessions. The selection process involves multiple rounds of voting, with the candidate receiving the fewest votes being eliminated in each round.  ( 56 min )

    One person has been found dead and two others have been rescued after two freighters collided in the North Sea off the coast of Germany. The Verity, which sank, was on its way from Bremen to Immingham, while the Polesie was sailing from Hamburg to La Coruna. The vessels' cargoes are unknown. Four people from the Verity are still missing, while the Polesie had 22 people on board, none of whom were injured. Strong winds and waves were reported in the area.  ( 41 min )

    We Are Now Living In A Multi-Polar World
    Moon Of Alabama: The Penny Drops - The World Is Multi-Polar¬† In 2007, during his famous speech in Munich, the Russian President Vladimir Putin pointed to the inevitable rise of a multipolar world.¬† He started out by defining the opposite state:¬† ¬†¬† However, what is a unipolar world? However one might embellish this term, at the end of the day it refers to one type of situation, namely one centre of authority, one centre of force, one centre of decision-making.¬† ¬†¬† It is world in which there is one master, one sovereign. And at the end of the day this is pernicious not only for all those within this system, but also for the sovereign itself because it destroys itself from within. Read more .... ¬† WNU Editor: All that I can add to the above column is that I never expected this change to be happening as quickly as it is now.

    Poll: Americans Overwhelmingly Back Giving Aid To Israel And Ukraine
    Photo Credit: Reuters ¬† USA Today: Poll: Americans overwhelmingly back aid to Israel and Ukraine but split on US role in the world ¬† The debate over military aid and global leadership has opened a generation gap and a partisan divide, a new USA TODAY/Suffolk poll finds.¬† Most Americans support sending additional military aid to Israel and Ukraine, a new USA TODAY/Suffolk University Poll finds, but a divide is deepening between those who see U.S. global leadership as crucial and those who want to pull back from the world to focus on problems at home instead.¬† The survey found double-digit support for aid to Israel in its battle against the terrorist group Hamas, 58%-35%, and majority support for sending more aid to Ukraine in its war with Russia, 51%-43%.¬† Additional military aid to Taiwan, which faces a continuing threat from China, was backed by a smaller margin, 43%-39%.¬† The poll of 1,000 registered voters, taken Oct. 17-20 by landline and cell phone, has a margin of error of plus or minus 3.1 percentage points.¬† Read more .... ¬† WNU Editor: This explains why politically the White House sees their policy towards Ukraine and Israel as a winning one in the 2024 election cycle.

    Brazil: A Step Forward for Indigenous Peoples Rights
    MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Oct 24 (IPS) - Brazil‚Äôs Supreme Court has delivered a long-awaited ruling upholding Brazilian Indigenous peoples‚Äô claims to their traditional land. It did so by rejecting the ‚ÄòTemporal Framework‚Äô principle, which only allowed for the demarcation and titling of lands physically occupied by the Indigenous groups who claimed them by 5 October 1988, when the current constitution was adopted. This excluded the numerous Indigenous communities who‚Äôd been violently expelled from their ancestral lands before then, including under military dictatorship between 1964 and 1985.     White House Says Iran Is 'Facilitating' Attacks On US Middle East Troops

    This Is How The CIA Is Waging A 'Hot War' Against Russia
    Washington Post: Ukrainian spies with deep ties to CIA wage shadow war against Russia¬† KYIV ‚Äî The cluttered car carrying a mother and her 12-year-old daughter seemed barely worth the attention of Russian security officials as it approached a border checkpoint.¬† But the least conspicuous piece of luggage ‚Äî a crate for a cat ‚Äî was part of an elaborate, lethal plot. Ukrainian operatives had installed a hidden compartment in the pet carrier, according to security officials with knowledge of the operation, and used it to conceal components of a bomb.¬† Four weeks later, the device detonated just outside Moscow in an SUV being driven by the daughter of a Russian nationalist who had urged his country to ‚Äúkill, kill, kill‚Äù Ukrainians, an explosion signaling that the heart of Russia would not be spared the carnage of war.¬† Read more ....¬† Update #1: Ukraine‚Äôs CIA-Trained Intelligence Operators Assassinated Dozens of Russians, Collaborators ‚Äì WaPo (Moscow Times)¬† Update #2: CIA closely cooperates with Ukraine and invests dozens of dollars there ‚Äì WP (Ukrainska Pravda)¬† WNU Editor: This story is being covered comprehensively in Russia ....     Politico: Swiss election results: Far right dominates after anti-immigration campaign¬† Final results show sizeble gains for the far-right Swiss People‚Äôs Party, and important losses for the Greens.¬† The far-right and euroskeptic Swiss People‚Äôs Party (SVP) came out as a clear leader in Switzerland‚Äôs national elections, according to final results released late Sunday.¬† The SVP, which has centered its campaign on anti-immigrant rhetoric in an election dominated by domestic issues, has won 28.6 percent of the vote in the Parliament‚Äôs lower chamber, the National Council ‚Äî up from 25.6 percent four years ago ‚Äî winning 62 seats, nine more than in 2019.¬† While the centrist The Center party maintained its score at 14.6 percent (29 seats), the liberal FDP party suffered a small loss, losing one seat. ¬† Read more ....¬† Swiss Right-Wing Populists Strengthen Hold After Federal Elections ¬† A Swiss populist party rebounds and the Greens sink in the election.     U.S. President Biden: "I Am A Zionist"
    Reuters: 'I am a Zionist': How Joe Biden's lifelong bond with Israel shapes war policy¬† WASHINGTON (Reuters) - When Joe Biden met with Prime Minister Netanyahu and his war cabinet during his visit to Israel, the U.S. president assured them: "I don't believe you have to be a Jew to be a Zionist, and I am a Zionist."¬† The politicians and generals gathered in the ballroom of the Tel Aviv hotel nodded in approval, according to a U.S. official knowledgeable of the closed-door remarks, even as Israel bombarded Gaza in retaliation for a devastating attack by Palestinian Hamas militants and with a ground invasion looming.¬† Biden, who is of Irish Catholic descent, has used similar words in the past to profess his affinity for Israel. But the moment, which has not been previously reported, illustrates how Biden's decades as one of the leading "Friends of Israel" in American politics seem to be guiding him during a defining crisis of his presidency. ¬† Read more .... ¬† WNU Editor:¬†I guess this explains why many American Muslims are deserting the US President .... ‚ÄòThe man broke my heart‚Äô: Biden‚Äôs Arab-American boosters begin to leave his side (Politico).

(U.S. Air Force) ¬† Stars and Stripes: Nearly 70% of US troops are overweight or obese, research report says ¬† WASHINGTON ‚Äî Almost seven out of every 10 U.S. troops are either overweight or obese, according to a new report, which also warns the growing trend could compromise military readiness and undermine national security.¬† The American Security Project, a Washington-based nonprofit organization that studies modern national security issues, conducted the study and found 68% of active-duty service members fall somewhere between overweight and obese on the body mass index, which is a long-used but controversial method of assessing a person‚Äôs body classification by height and weight.¬† A person between 25 and 30 on the BMI is considered clinically overweight and more than 30 is considered obese, according to the National Institutes of Health. ¬† Read more .... ¬† WNU Editor: 70% !?!?!?!?!?     Pakistan SC declares trial of civilians in military courts null and void
    Pakistan's Supreme Court has declared the trials of civilians in military courts to be null and void. The court ruled that citizens have the right to a fair trial under the constitution. A five-judge bench of the top court headed by Justice Ijazul Ahsan announced the verdict with a 4-1 majority. The court declared Section 2(1)(d) of the Army Act, which elaborates on persons subject to the act, to be in violation of the constitution and ‚Äúof no legal effect‚Äù.  ( 43 min )
    'We're in battle of civilisation against barbarism': Netanyahu to Dutch PM
    Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu met with Dutch Prime Minister Mark Rutte and emphasized the need for unity against Hamas, stating that "Hamas is ISIS." Rutte expressed his respect for Israel's efforts to defend against the attacks and restore safety. Netanyahu highlighted the severity of the situation, describing it as a battle of humanity against barbarism. Prior to the meeting, Netanyahu had conversations with the leaders of France, Spain, and the Netherlands, discussing Israel's determination to eliminate Hamas's military capabilities.  ( 45 min )
    Fifth death confirmed in UK after Storm Babet
    A fifth death has been confirmed in the UK following the severe weather brought by Storm Babet. The body of a man was found after he went missing in flood waters in Aberdeenshire, Scotland. This brings the total number of deaths in Scotland to three, with two additional deaths in England. Thousands of homes have been flooded and several hundred people are homeless. The storm has also caused damage in Germany, Norway, and Denmark. The UK is still on alert with more heavy rain expected.  ( 41 min )
    Taliban exploiting international aid through 'fraudulent' NGOs, says US watchdog
    The Taliban in Afghanistan are benefiting from international aid through fraudulent NGOs, according to a report by the US Special Inspector General for Afghanistan Reconstruction. The Taliban has increased control over NGOs since seizing power in August 2021, using tactics such as extorting and infiltrating existing organizations. They have also barred Afghan women from NGO work and sought to push out foreign organizations from the education sector.  ( 46 min )
    Iran hosts Armenia-Azerbaijan talks, says they offer chance of South Caucasus peace
    Iran hosted talks between the foreign ministers of Armenia and Azerbaijan, aiming to bring peace to the South Caucasus region. The talks took place against the backdrop of rising tensions in the Middle East. Iran's Foreign Minister emphasized the need for peace and cooperation, urging the removal of outside interference. The talks were attended by the foreign ministers of Russia and Turkey, and Iran expressed its readiness to assist in resolving the disputes between Armenia and Azerbaijan.  ( 45 min )
    UK PM announces extra ¬£20 million aid for civilians in Gaza
    The UK has announced an additional ¬£20 million ($24 million) of aid to help civilians in Gaza affected by the conflict between Israel and Hamas. This brings the total amount pledged by Britain to Palestinian territories to ¬£30 million. The UK had previously committed ¬£27 million to Palestinians this year. UK leader Rishi Sunak also stated that the explosion at the Al-Ahli hospital in Gaza was likely caused by a missile fired from within Gaza, based on intelligence analysis.  ( 45 min )
    Gaza neonatal unit warns babies at risk 'within minutes' if power fails
    Doctors in Gaza are in desperate need of fuel and basic medicines for their neonatal intensive care unit. The lack of electricity could result in the death of babies within minutes if their incubators lose power. The hospitals in Gaza are running out of fuel and are appealing to the world for help. The Israeli siege on Gaza has led to shortages of water, food, medicines, and fuel for the 2.3 million people living there. The situation is dire, with thousands of Palestinians killed and injured in Israeli air strikes.  ( 50 min )
    Erdogan submits Sweden's NATO bid to Turkish parliament
    Turkey's President Recep Tayyip Erdogan has officially submitted Sweden's NATO membership application to parliament, bringing closer the end of a 17-month diplomatic standoff. Sweden dropped its policy of non-alignment last year after Russia's war on Ukraine, prompting its request for NATO membership. Hungary and Turkey are the only NATO members yet to ratify Sweden's membership. Erdogan agreed to put the ratification before the Turkish parliament at a NATO summit in July.  ( 40 min )
    Tragic fall claims worker's life in downtown Boston's high-rise
    On Monday morning in downtown Boston, a tragic incident occurred as an individual fell from a high-rise office tower, resulting in their unfortunate demise, as confirmed by the police, reported NBC Boston. Regrettably, the worker who plummeted did not survive, as reported by law enforcement.  ( 40 min )
    Eyeing EU election, Orban calls Brussels a 'bad contemporary parody'
    Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orban criticized the leaders of the European Union (EU) during his campaign for the upcoming European Parliamentary elections. Orban referred to Brussels as a "bad contemporary parody" and expressed his belief that it can still be fixed. The EU has suspended funding to Hungary over concerns about the rule of law, complicating Orban's efforts to revive the country's economy. Despite his combative tone, Orban's top negotiator expressed optimism about resolving the funding dispute.  ( 46 min )
    More than 19,000 displaced in Lebanon amid tensions on Israeli border: UN agency
    Over 19,000 people have been displaced in Lebanon due to increased tensions between Israel and Hezbollah at the southern border, according to the International Organization for Migration. The organization expects these numbers to rise as tensions continue to escalate. The displacement adds additional stress to the already struggling resources of host communities in Lebanon, which is grappling with political paralysis, an economic crisis, and a fragile health system.  ( 48 min )
    Book critical of Ming emperor recalled after prompting online comparisons with Xi
    A book that drew comparisons between an inept Chinese emperor and President Xi Jinping has been pulled from shelves in China. The book, titled "Chongzhen: The Diligent Emperor of a Fallen Dynasty was recalled on October 16, due to "printing problems", its publisher, Dook Media Group, said in an online notice. Chongzhen, whose reign ended with his suicide in 1644, was noted by historians for his diligence as much as his paranoia, including the constant questioning of his subjects' loyalty.  ( 47 min )
    At least 20 killed, scores injured as two trains collide in Bangladesh
    At least 20 people are feared dead and over 100 injured after two trains collided in Bangladesh.Officials fear that the toll could rise further with a significant number of people sustaining injuries.According to AFP, the crash took place in the eastern city of Bhairab when a freight train smashed into a passenger train travelling in the opposite direction.The collision caused two passenger carriages to derail, officials said. "We have recovered 15 bodies, many are injured," Sadiqur Rahman, a government administrator in Bhairab told AFP.  ( 40 min )

    Israel continues to bombard Gaza with air strikes while soldiers fight Hamas militants on the ground. The conflict has also spread to southern Lebanon and the occupied West Bank. The United Nations warns that civilians in Gaza are running out of food, water, and shelter. Aid is slowly trickling into Gaza, but it is not enough to meet the needs of the population. Both Israel and Hamas reported overnight clashes in Gaza, with Israel conducting limited raids and airstrikes and gathering information on hostages held by Hamas. .  ( 57 min )
    Israel mounts limited Gaza ground raids, Hamas says it engages attackers
    Israel's military has conducted limited raids into the Gaza Strip, targeting sites where Palestinian militants are assembling. The raids, which involved tank and infantry forces, aimed to eliminate terrorist squads preparing for the next stage of the conflict. Israel's chief military spokesperson also stated that these interventions help gather intelligence on missing persons and hostages. The armed wing of Hamas claimed to have engaged with an infiltrating Israeli force, destroying two bulldozers and a tank. The Israeli military has not yet commented on these claims.  ( 44 min )
    Cyprus busts refugee trafficking ring as more arrive from Mideast
    Police in Cyprus on Monday arrested ten individuals suspected of running a crime gang trafficking migrants, as the island saw a fresh spike in arrivals over the weekend. Cyprus, which lies at the crossroads of three continents, has seen irregular migration rise since 2017. Cypriot officials have in recent days repeatedly expressed concern that the rapidly deteriorating security situation in the Middle East could lead to a surge in people fleeing the area.  ( 40 min )
    China says outlook worrisome as conflict spreads in Middle East: State media
    China's Middle East special envoy, Zhai Jun, has expressed concern about the situation in Gaza, stating that the risk of a large-scale ground conflict is growing. He highlighted the conflict spilling over into neighboring regions, including along the Israeli-Lebanese and Israeli-Syrian borders. Zhai called on the international community to be vigilant and take immediate action to avoid a serious humanitarian disaster. China is willing to promote dialogue, achieve a ceasefire, restore peace, and support a two-state solution.  ( 44 min )
    Iran jails 2 journalists who covered hijab death row, for 'collaborating with US'
    Two journalists in Iran have been sentenced to up to seven years in prison for collaborating with the US government and other charges. Niloufar Hamedi and Elaheh Mohammadi were imprisoned for over a year following their coverage of Mahsa Amini's death in police custody. The New York-based Committee to Protect Journalists has condemned the decision and called for their release. The journalists were charged with collaborating with the US government, colluding against national security, and propaganda against the system.     How palm oil companies are illegally burning forests to clear land in Indonesia
    Indonesian palm oil companies have been playing a dangerous game: burning forests to clear land that has already been dried out by their activities¬†‚Äì just to cut production costs. This practice is illegal because it is a major cause of wildfires that have destroyed ecosystems and generated massive atmospheric pollution in Indonesia and nearby countries over the past few years.     Trump plots 'tremendously stupid' NATO plan for his second term: report
    Former President Donald Trump is pushing for a major American foreign policy change in his second administration that would likely upend decades of global national security infrastructure. Sources tell Rolling Stone that Trump is planning to pull the United States entirely out of the North Atlantic Treaty Alliance unless it caves to his demands that include one that would seem to undermine the entire purpose of the alliance. In addition to his standard calls for other NATO countries to chip in more for their defense spending, Trump also reportedly wants to rip up the strategic doctrine that an attack on one NATO country represents an attack on all NATO countries. POLL: Should Trump be allowed to run for office? "When he was in office, Trump would repeatedly scoff at this collective-defense clause of the North Atlantic Treaty, known as Article 5," the publication writes. "One former senior administration official recalls to Rolling Stone a moment in the Oval Office in mid-2018 when the then-president started reading from a written list of smaller NATO countries, some of which he argued most Americans had never even heard of before." Tearing up Article 5 would be a major boon for the likes of Russia, which attacked non-NATO member Ukraine in 2022 but notably has not attacked other NATO members on its border such as Estonia and Latvia. Dr. Aaron Stein, a Black Sea Fellow at the Foreign Policy Research Institute, tells Rolling Stone that Trump's plan would be a "tremendously stupid endeavor" and added that "trading away allies based on ignorance, and Trump is ignorant about this issue, is just silly for broader U.S. national security."  ( 44 min )

    Web Summit chief resigns after Israel comments furor
    The organiser of the Web Summit, one of the tech sector's leading events, announced his resignation Saturday following a backlash over his online posts following the Hamas attacks on Israel. "Unfortunately, my personal comments have become a distraction from the event," Paddy Cosgrave of Ireland explained in a brief statement sent to AFP. "I sincerely apologize again for any hurt I have caused," added the co-founder of the tech mega gathering created in 2009 in Dublin but held in Lisbon since 2016. A spokesperson for the organization said: "Web Summit will appoint a new CEO as soon as possible, and Web Summit 2023 in Lisbon will go ahead as planned." This year's edition from November 13 to 16, is set to bring together some 2,300 startups and more than 70,000 participants, say organizers. Several companies, including tech giants Google and Meta, which is behind Facebook and Instagram, as well as event headliners have announced they are boycotting the gathering since Cosgrave's remarks. He had written on X, formerly Twitter, that he was "shocked at the rhetoric and actions of so many Western leaders & governments" in support of Israel. "War crimes are war crimes even when committed by allies, and should be called out for what they are," he wrote on October 13. Since shock Hamas attacks on Israel on October 7, which left 1,400 dead, Israel has launched devastating air and ground bombardments of Gaza. The Hamas authorities say 4,385 people have died.     Hurricane Norma makes landfall in Mexico as Category 1 storm
    Hurricane Norma slammed into Mexico's northwestern coast Saturday afternoon as a Category 1 storm, bringing dangerous rain and flooding, authorities said. The storm came ashore about 25 kilometers (15 miles) northwest of the resort city of Cabo San Lucas on the Baja California coast, gradually weakening from a Category 3 as it approached land. Norma was moving northeast at 9 kph, packing winds of up to 130 kph, the National Hurricane Center (NHC) reported at 2100 GMT. Norma was expected to bring rainfall of up to 45 centimeters (18 inches), producing "flash and urban flooding, along with mudslides in areas of higher terrain," the NHC said. "Life-threatening surf and rip current conditions" would affect the coast of southwestern and west-central Mexico and Baja California Sur for the next couple of days. Hotel employees in Cabo San Lucas urged guests to stay indoors until authorities give the all-clear, Gustavo Matamoros, a hotel worker, told AFP. Local authorities say about 60,000 tourists are staying in the area, most of them international visitors. Footage from Milenio TV showed flooded streets as Norma arrived. No casualties have been reported by authorities. Norma should continue to weaken to a tropical storm as it moves toward the west coast of Mexico on Sunday. Two people died last week when Hurricane Lidia struck the western states of Jalisco and Nayarit. ¬© Agence France-Presse  ( 44 min )

    Cow plague threatening ranches in southern Europe
    Epizootic Hemorrhagic Disease, or EHD, is typically found in the tropics and affects cattle, deer and other animals. But due to abnormally high temperatures in Europe, cases are now spreading quickly across Spain, Italy and France. The virus causes internal bleeding, miscarriages and sterility. It's rarely fatal, but ranchers are concerned for their animals and livelihoods.

    Israel 'accidentally' fires at Egyptian post; 2nd aid convoy on way to Gaza
    A second aid convoy entered the Egyptian side of the Rafah border crossing on Sunday, heading towards Gaza. Shortly after the convoy entered, a blast was heard and seven people were wounded. The Israeli military said one of its tanks accidentally fired and hit an Egyptian position near the border. The Egyptian military said the blast caused minor injuries and that an investigation is underway. The convoy carried medical and food supplies, and distribution of the supplies began on Sunday. However, aid officials are warning of a humanitarian disaster as supplies run low.  ( 41 min )
    Antisemitism, Islamophobia on rise in West
    Advocacy groups have reported a significant increase in antisemitic and Islamophobic incidents in the US and Europe since the recent Hamas attacks in Israel. The Anti-Defamation League recorded a 55% rise in antisemitic incidents in the US compared to the same period last year. There have also been spikes in anti-Israel rallies and antisemitic harassment on messaging apps. Similarly, the Council on American-Islamic Relations reported an increase in anti-Muslim incidents in the past week. In the UK, anti-Muslim attacks have increased sixfold, while France and Germany have also seen a rise in antisemitic incidents.  ( 42 min )
    How diplomacy helped set free mom-daughter
    US Secretary of State Antony Blinken spoke with Qatar's PM about the issue of the hostages held by Hamas during the recent attack on Israel. Qatar played a significant role in delicate talks involving multiple countries to secure the release of the captives. When Hamas released two captives, the Raanan family, US officials thanked Qatar for their involvement. Families of the remaining hostages hope this is just the beginning.     Israel strikes a 'terror compound' in West Bank
    The Israeli military conducted an airstrike on a mosque in the occupied West Bank, resulting in the death of at least two people. The strike targeted an underground compound allegedly being used by Hamas and Islamic Jihad for organizing an imminent attack. The Palestinian foreign ministry condemned the airstrike as a "dangerous escalation" and accused Israel of using tactics from the Gaza Strip in the West Bank. Violence in the area has increased following recent attacks by Hamas.  ( 41 min )
    Pentagon sees threat to US troops in West Asia, beefs up military assets
    US officials, including Secretary of State Antony Blinken and Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin, have expressed concerns about the potential escalation of attacks on US troops in the West Asia region. They also mentioned the possibility of Iran trying to expand the Israel-Hamas conflict. The US has recently deployed additional military assets to the region, including a Thaad battery and extra Patriot battalions, to prevent the conflict from spreading. The US has already sent significant naval power and has troops stationed in Iraq and Syria.  ( 42 min )
    Israel pummels Gaza amid fear of wider war
    The Israel-Hamas conflict has raised concerns about a wider conflict in the region. Israel has continued to bombard Gaza, with the death toll rising. Clashes between Hezbollah and Israeli forces along the Lebanon border have also escalated. Israeli missiles have hit airports in Syria, where Iran has a military presence. Israel has warned of a potential ground offensive in Gaza, while also evacuating communities close to the Lebanon border. The situation remains tense, with fears of further escalation.  ( 46 min )

    South East Asia celebrates Netaji, reaffirms to honour legacy
    The chief minister of Penang, Malaysia, Chow Kon Yeow, attended a commemorative event for Netaji Subhash Chandra Bose, marking the 80th anniversary of the provisional government and INA Raising Day. He expressed pride that Netaji had chosen Malaysia as a base to organize Indians against British colonial rule. In Bangkok, the Netaji Subhash Vision Thailand organization celebrated the anniversary with a 3-day "Netaji Pilgrimage" for academics and Indo-Thai citizens connected to Bose's historical visits to Thailand. The first-ever INA training camp was built in Chonburi, Thailand, where Indian migrant families supported Netaji's cause.  ( 43 min )
    China to build world's largest underwater 'ghost particle' detector
    China is constructing the world's largest underwater microscope, the Tropical Deep-sea Neutrino Telescope (TRIDENT), to hunt for elusive neutrinos or "ghost particles" in the Western Pacific Ocean. Set to be completed in 2030, TRIDENT aims to capture neutrinos as they become detectable in the deep ocean depths, providing insights into their cosmic origins.  ( 42 min )
    Pulitzer winner's New York talk cancelled over Gaza stand
    Viet Thanh Nguyen, a Pulitzer Prize-winning author, had a reading event cancelled by a Jewish organization in New York City, a day after he signed an open letter condemning Israel's actions in Gaza. The organization, 92nd Street Y, postponed the event without giving a reason or offering an alternative date. The organization cited Nguyen's stance on Israel and the recent attack by Hamas as reasons for the postponement. Nguyen's representatives have not commented on the cancellation.  ( 40 min )
    Pangea Ultima: The uninhabitable supercontinent of Earth's distant future
    Scientists at the University of Bristol have used supercomputer climate models to predict the formation of a future supercontinent called Pangea Ultima, which is expected to occur 250 million years from now. This continent will bring extreme temperatures, rendering it uninhabitable for mammals. The study attributes the dramatic increase in temperatures to heightened volcanism and the sun emitting more energy and heat as it ages. The research provides insights into how Earth's climate might change in the distant future due to natural processes. Despite concerns about contemporary climate change, the Earth is expected to remain habitable until the emergence of Pangea Ultima.  ( 47 min )
    Geological time capsules: Diamonds tell the tale of Earth's ancient continents
    An international team of experts has analyzed ancient superdeep diamonds found in mines in Brazil and Western Africa to gain new insights into the early evolution of complex life on Earth. These rare diamonds, formed within the supercontinent Gondwana, provide information about the formation and movement of supercontinents. The research reveals that supercontinents played a role in concentrating deep oceanic plate subduction. The diamonds formed deep beneath Gondwana and were carried to the surface during volcanic eruptions.  ( 49 min )
    Amazon testing humanoid robots in its warehouses
    Amazon plans to test Agility's bipedal robot, Digit, in its nationwide fulfillment centers. Amazon Robotics has primarily focused on wheeled autonomous mobile robots (AMRs), but their interest in Digit shows their curiosity about walking robots and their potential. The integration of humanoid robots into Amazon's operations raises questions about scalability and adaptability. While this early-stage deal may not guarantee broader adoption, it highlights Amazon's interest in exploring robotics.  ( 44 min )
    Pope, Biden discuss Israel-Hamas conflict, other wars

The focus of their discussion was on addressing conflict situations worldwide and finding ways to promote peace. In parallel news, Israel is preparing for a ground assault on Gaza, prompted by a recent Hamas attack in Israel that resulted in the loss of 1,400 lives.  ( 41 min )
    Argentina heads to polls in grip of fierce economic crisis
    Argentines will vote in a general election on Sunday amid the country's worst economic crisis in two decades. The far-right libertarian candidate Javier Milei is in pole position to win, promising to bring about radical change in the economy and politics. However, centrist Peronist Economy Minister Sergio Massa and conservative Patricia Bullrich are also strong contenders. The election outcome will have significant implications for Argentina's markets, trade relationships, and political trajectory.  ( 47 min )
    Amid slump in economy, Pakistanis migrating abroad for better opportunities
    Amid an economic downturn and hyperinflation, many Pakistanis, particularly the younger generation, are seeking opportunities abroad for employment and scholarships. Over 450,000 Pakistanis are reported to have emigrated in the first three months of 2023. Passport offices and immigration centers are witnessing long queues as people rush to obtain passports and visas. The British Council is also experiencing a surge in work and student visa applications. Some believe that this mass exodus can lead to increased international remittances benefiting Pakistan.  ( 43 min )

    Israel Is Now Fighting On 3 Fronts
    Insider: Israel is now fighting on 3 fronts as airstrikes and violence escalate across the Palestinian territories, Lebanon, and Syria¬† ¬†* Israel is now waging war on three fronts ‚Äî the Palestinian territories, Lebanon, and Syria.¬† ¬†* As the conflict spreads, the US is beefing up its military presence in the region.¬† ¬†* US Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin said it was in response to "recent escalations by Iran and its proxy forces."¬† Following the Palestinian militant group Hamas' attacks on Israel on October 7, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu declared war on the group.¬† Now, that conflict is spilling over into the neighboring countries of Lebanon and Syria as Israel ramps up airstrikes on the two Arab states.¬† The US has sent more military assets to the region to bolster Israel's forces following what US Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin called "recent escalations by Iran and its proxy forces." ¬† Read more .... ¬† WNU Editor: The Israeli - Hamas war will play itself out, but it is Hezbollah in southern Lebanon who I would be concerned about.

    U.S. Accuses China's Military Of Coercive And Risky Behaviors In The Indo-Pacific Region

    Chinese Coast Guard Ship Deliberately Collides With Philippine Supply Vessel In South China Sea
    CNN: China and Philippines accuse each other over collisions in disputed South China Sea ¬† China and the Philippines on Sunday accused each other of causing collisions in a disputed area of the South China Sea, the latest in a string of maritime confrontations between the two countries that have heightened regional tensions.¬† In a statement, Philippine authorities said a Chinese Coast Guard ship carried out ‚Äúdangerous blocking maneuvers‚Äù that caused it to collide with a Philippine vessel carrying supplies to troops stationed in Ayungin Shoal, also known as Second Thomas Shoal, in the Spratly Islands chain.¬† China‚Äôs move was ‚Äúprovocative, irresponsible and illegal‚Äù and ‚Äúimperiled the safety of the crew‚Äù of the Philippine boats, the National Task Force for the West Philippine Sea said. ¬† Read more ....¬† WNU Editor: It is a ticking time bomb ....     Who is responsible for Turkey‚Äôs bad buildings?
    Buildings destroyed after the earthquake on February 13, 2023, in Hatay, Turkey. | Murat Saka/dia images via Getty Images Turkey is investigating and has arrested some contractors, but the entire political and economic system is implicated. Turkey is still in the middle of an emergency, reeling from the earthquake that killed at least 35,000 people last week. But the finger-pointing has already begun.     10 years ago, we were turning nuclear bombs into nuclear energy. We can do it again.
    Getty Images How we turned 20,000 Soviet nukes into zero-carbon energy ‚Äî and how we can do the same with some of our own. Just a decade ago, one in 10 American lightbulbs was powered by dismantled Russian nuclear weapons. That was made possible by the Megatons to Megawatts program, an agreement negotiated after the collapse of the Soviet Union to convert uranium from Russia‚Äôs nuclear weapons stockpile into fuel for US nuclear power plants. The unconventional policy was first proposed by MIT physicist Thomas Neff in a 1991 New York Times op-ed. By the time Megatons to Megawatts ran its full course from 1993 to 2013, it had eliminated about 20,000 nuclear warheads and stood out as a point of shared pride in the often jaded arms control and disarmament field. ‚ÄúNearly every commercia‚Ä¶  ( 15 min )

    Why earthquakes are deadlier depending on where you live
    Volunteers stand on rubble of a destroyed building in Kahramanmaras, Turkey, on February 7, 2023. | Adem Altan/AFP via Getty Images What Turkey and Syria‚Äôs deadly earthquakes reveal about wealth. In the early hours of Monday, February 6, residents living in southern Turkey and northern Syria were woken by violent shaking, collapsing buildings, and sweeping blackouts. The earthquake buried residents in rubble and was followed by powerful aftershocks. By the following Monday, the death toll had passed 36,000 people. ‚ÄúIt was like the apocalypse,‚Äù Abdul Salam al-Mahmoud, a resident of Atareb, Syria, told Reuters.
